audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.pacing: 60–75 minutes; 3 grammar-focused sections with quick drills.
teacher_notes.materials: Slide deck, grammar reference sheet, and mini whiteboards for response.
teacher_notes.assessment: Unit check and correction of common errors from practice.

learning_objectives: Edit sentences for clarity and correct structure.
Apply punctuation rules for commas, dashes, and colons.

structure.title: Sentence Structure
objectives: Identify and correct fragments and run-ons.

lecture_script.script: Complete sentences need a subject and a finite verb and express a full idea. Join related ideas with proper punctuation or conjunctions.
We’ll fix two run-ons by adding conjunctions or splitting into two sentences, keeping meaning concise.
Is this a fragment, a run-on, or correct? Hold up F, R, or C.

worked_example.passage: The museum expanded last year it opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.
worked_example.question: Which choice best corrects the sentence?

options.A: The museum expanded last year opening two new galleries devoted to modern art.
options.B: The museum expanded last year; it opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.
options.C: Because the museum expanded last year, and opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.
options.D: The museum expanded last year, it opened two new galleries devoted to modern art.

worked_example.explanation: Option B correctly joins two independent clauses with a semicolon.

practice_set.passage: Hoping to finish early and to catch the bus on time.
practice_set.question: Which revision creates a complete sentence?

options.A: Hoping to finish early, the team worked quickly and caught the bus.
options.B: Hoping to finish early; and to catch the bus on time.
options.C: Hoping to finish early catching the bus on time.
options.D: Hoping to finish early on time bus.

structure.title: Punctuation
objectives: Use commas for nonessential information and series.
Apply colons to introduce explanations or lists.
Use dashes for emphasis or appositives when appropriate.

lecture_script.script: Commas set off nonessential phrases; colons follow complete clauses to introduce explanations; dashes can replace commas for emphasis.
We’ll test whether the clause before a colon is complete, then decide between comma, colon, or dash.
Is the information essential? If not, set it off with commas or dashes.

worked_example.passage: The recipe calls for three ingredients simple ones: flour, water, and salt.
worked_example.question: Which choice correctly uses punctuation?

options.A: The recipe calls for three ingredients: simple ones, flour, water, and salt.
options.B: The recipe calls for three ingredients-simple ones: flour, water, and salt.
options.C: The recipe calls for three ingredients: simple ones-flour, water, and salt.
options.D: The recipe calls for three ingredients: flour, water, and salt.

worked_example.explanation: A complete clause precedes a colon that introduces a list; no extra words are needed.

practice_set.passage: The festival featured dancers musicians and poets from across the region.
practice_set.question: Which choice correctly punctuates the sentence?

options.A: The festival featured dancers, musicians, and poets from across the region.
options.B: The festival featured dancers; musicians and poets from across the region.
options.C: The festival featured dancers musicians, and poets, from across the region.
options.D: The festival featured dancers-musicians-and poets from across the region.

structure.title: Usage & Agreement
objectives: Ensure subject-verb agreement, even with interrupting phrases.
Maintain pronoun clarity and agreement in number and person.
Choose precise, conventional usage over awkward phrasing.

lecture_script.script: Match the verb to the true subject, not to nearby nouns. Keep pronouns clear and consistent with their antecedents.
We’ll identify subjects in tricky sentences and adjust verbs or pronouns accordingly.
State the subject and the correct verb form in two words each.

worked_example.passage: The bouquet of roses and lilies were fragrant enough to fill the room.
worked_example.question: Which choice corrects the error?

options.A: The bouquet of roses and lilies was fragrant enough to fill the room.
options.B: The bouquets of roses and lilies was fragrant enough to fill the room.
options.C: The bouquet of roses and lilies were fragrant enough to fill the rooms.
options.D: The bouquet of roses and lilies are fragrant enough to fill the room.

worked_example.explanation: Subject is ‘bouquet’ (singular), so the verb should be ‘was.’

practice_set.passage: Neither the coach nor the players ___ ready for the photo when it was taken.
practice_set.question: Which verb correctly completes the sentence?

options.B: a subject and a finite verb

options.A: set off with commas or dashes

homework: Fix ten sentences containing fragments, run-ons, or comma splices.
Add correct punctuation to five sentences with lists or explanations.
Revise five sentences for agreement and clear pronoun reference.
